subject: Learning
title: Peer Learning in Childhood
description: A quick, practical guide to Peer Learning in Childhood.

hook.text: A five-year-old explains fractions to a classmate better than the teacher did. Children are natural peer tutors.

buildup.text: Peer learning occurs when children learn from and with each other, often more effectively than from adults.

discovery.text: Peers operate closer to each other's zone of proximal development, making explanations naturally calibrated.

twist.text: The tutor benefits as much as the tutee. Explaining forces reorganization of knowledge and deeper understanding.

climax.text: Cooperative learning structuresâ€”where children work together toward shared goalsâ€”outperform competitive ones.

punchline.text: Children teach children best. They speak the same language of understanding.

quiz.question: Why are peer explanations often more effective than adult instruction?
options: Peers operate closer to each other's zone of proximal development
Children always explain things more accurately than adults
Adults are unable to communicate with children effectively
